Carli, C.L. Bianchi, R. Giannantonio and V. Ragaini* Department of Physical Chemistry and Electrochemistry, University of Milan, Via Golgi 19, 20133 Milan (Italy); tel. (+39-2)26603244, fax. (+39-2)270638129 (Received June 25, 1992; accepted March 22, 1993 ) Abstract Several experiments were performed to provide convincing evidence for low temperature gallium reduction in a Ga203/HZSM-5 catalyst. XPS measurements showed the appearance of a GaI signal after in situ hydrogen reduction at temperatures ranging between 373 and 673 K. No transfer of reduced gallium species from Ga203 to the zeolite particles was detected. A revision of the existing reduction mechanism is thus proposed. It is suggested here that the actual role of the HZSM-5 zeolite could be to provide a kind of activated hydrogen able to reduce Ga203. Key words: in situ reduction, XPS measurements, gallium oxidation state, activated hydrogen Introduction Recently, some researchers outlined the strategic importance of producing aromatic hydrocarbons, as benzene, toluene and xylenes (BTX), by new processes using liquiiied petroleum gas (LPG) [ 1-2 ] . The aromatization of light paraffins as made in M2 [ 3 ] and Cyclar [ 4 ] processes is of extreme interest. In particular the Cyclar process, developed jointly by BP (catalyst) and UOP (regeneration technology), is based on a Ga-promoted zeolite catalyst prepared by a standard impregnation procedure of a zeolite, usually the acidic form of ZSM-5 (HZSM-5) [5 ]. The Cyclar process has reached the final experimental period with the start up of a 1000 barrel/day process unit at the BP Oil Refinery in Grangemouth (UK) [6]. After the first demonstration trials, BP and UOP have announced the invention of a new catalyst formulation which permits a saving of 30% of the active component [ 7 ] . In spite of this extensive industrial work, which is documented by the wide patent literature available, recently reviewed by Seddon [8], some uncertainties on the actual role of the catalyst components (zeolite+promoter), their interactions and the nature of their active sites are still the subject of many *Corresponding author. 0304-5102/93/$06.00 1993 - Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. All rights reserved. 380 R. Carli et al. / J. Mol. Catal. 83 (1993) 379-389 discussions. This is mainly because the promoting effect of gallium is quite independent of the technique used in catalyst preparation. Thus the catalyst, prepared by wet impregnation or ion exchange, performs as well as a steamed gallosilicate [9,10 ] or a mechanical mixture of Ga203 and zeolite [ 11,12 ] . Because of this singular feature the catalytic cooperation between Ga203 and HZSM-5 could be explained in terms of one of the following: (i) a bifunctional catalyst, (ii) a remote control mechanism. The bifunctional catalyst mechanism is the most commonly reported in literature because (i) gallium, present as Ga203, seems to lie outside of the zeolite pore structure [ 13 ] ; (ii) Ga203 shows intrinsic activity in the dehydrogenation of small alkanes [ 14 ] . Moreover, the nature of the gallium promoting effect is, probably very complex; in fact, as recently reported by Bayense et al. [ 15 ] , some experimental results point to a dual nature of the gallium effect, distinguishable as short- and long-distance synergy between the zeolite acidic centre and the gallium site. In other words, one can consider an extraframework and a framework role of gallium species in promoting the catalyst selectivity to aromatics, as already discussed by Simmons et al. [ 10 ] . In this context a new perspective comes from a recent hypothesis on the solid state reaction which seems to occur between the zeolite acidic centre and the gallium species during a suitable activation procedure (reduction under hydrogen at 780-800 K) [ 16 ] . The proposed mechanism is mainly based on the following experimental evidence: Ga203 in the system H-zeolite/Ga203 can be reduced at temperatures lower than those reported for the reduction of pure Ga203- In order to elucidate this phenomenon, we have studied the evolution of the gallium oxidation state by high-resolution XPS measurements of Ga203 mixed with HZSM-5, after in situ hydrogen reduction treatments at low temperatures (373-673 K). A very interesting comparison with a sample reduced at 773 K is also proposed. Experimental Preparation of the samples The ZSM-5 zeolite (Si/A1=32.0) was synthesized according to the wellknown method of Argauer and Landolt [ 17 ] . XRD analysis showed the high crystallinity of our sample. The acid form of the zeolite, HZSM-5, was prepared by multiple ion-exchange treatments with a 0.1 M NH4C1 solution followed by drying and activation at 823 K. The final sodium content is 0.2 wt.%. Ga203 (99.99 wt.%, BET surface area= 4.2 m2/g) was purchased from Fluka. Dried Ga203 (15 wt.%) and HZSM-5 (85 wt.%) were dispersed in a suitable amount of distilled n-hexane (Fluka). This suspension of solids, kept under magnetic stirring, was submitted to US (ultrasonic) waves generated by a Branson Sonifier-B12 for 10 min. Most of the n-hexane was evaporated by means of a Buchi EL131 Rotavapor under a pressure less than atmospheric R. Carli et al. / J. Mol. Catal. 83 (1993) 379-389 381 pressure. Subsequent treatment in an oven at 363 K ensured the complete elimination of n-hexane. In the following, HZ/Ga203 stands for the Ga203 USmiged HZSM-5 sample. XPS apparatus X-ray photoelectron spectra were recorded in a Surface Science Instruments (now Fisons Instruments) M-Probe ESCA spectrometer (base pressure 5 X 10' Pa). Monochromated A1 Ka radiation (1486.60 eV) was used. Features of the instrument include a high-vacuum reaction chamber, allowing in situ thermal treatment under a controlled atmosphere [ 18 ] . Samples were pressed into a copper sample holder and outgassed at the operating pressure for 12 h; due to their insulating nature, a flood gun was used for complete charge neutralization. The (1s) level of adventitious carbon (atmospheric hydrocarbons and surface carbon oxides) was taken as the internal reference, with the peak position at 284.6 eV. Numerical and graphical elaborations of the spectra were performed by using the Surface Science Instruments software. The very high resolution of our spectrometer coupled with quite a robust peak deconvolution technique, allowed rather unambiguous qualitative surface analysis. The observed variation of R (T) function with temperature (oR (T) /8T < 0) reflects an increase of the surface concentration of reduced gallium species, GaI. For this reason, the R (T) function is a suitable way to visualize the reduction trend of the gallium surface species of our samples. In Fig. 5 we report the values of the R(T) function vs. T for pure Ga203 and HZ/Ga203. Transfer of gallium to HZSM-5 particles It is very difficult to assess the transfer of gallium onto (or into) the zeolite particles by means of XPS measurements, mainly because (i) the 3d electrons, ejected with a high kinetic energy (low binding energy ), have a large mean free path, the relative signal intensity being thus made up mainly by the photoemission from deeper atom layers, not the topmost [ 27,28 ] ; (ii) the relative abundance of an element with respect to another (chosen as the internal reference ) is estimated from the ratio of the deconvoluted peak areas; it must be noted that this ratio can be influenced by kinetic energy-dependent factors if the relevant chemical species have very different kinetic energies; in particular, a damping factor due to contaminating carbon overlayers cannot be excluded [27,28]. The above-mentioned considerations have some consequences on our system. In particular, the variation of Ga(3d) peak intensity due to surface migration from Ga203 onto (or into) the zeolite particles could be negligible as a consequence of reason (i). Discussion As reported by Price and Kanazirev [ 30-32 ], some experimental data indicates that the mixture of Ga203 and HZSM-5, heated at about 800 K in a hydrogen atmosphere, undergoes a singular reduction, resulting in an effective activation of the catalyst. On this basis they proposed the following mechanism: Ga2 03 + 2H +Z - + 2H2 --+ 2Ga'Z- + 3H2 0 (3) R. Carli et al. / J. Mot. Catal. 83 (1993) 379-389 387 where Z- stands for the zeolite centre. Equation (3) can be split into two steps [ 30 ] Ga203+2H2-+ Ga20 +2H20 (4a) Ga20 +2H+Z--.2Ga+Z-+H20 (4b) Although it was shown that Ga203adsorbs H2 [33 ], reaction (4a) cannot significantly proceed without (4b ), as is also demonstrated by the R (T) function trend of our Ga203 sample, reported in Fig. 5 (curve A). Actually, the small amount of reduced gallium is undetectable by XPS analysis. Thus, one can imagine that in a mixture of Ga203and HZSM-5 the small amount of Ga20 produced on the Ga203 surface, according to equation (4a), migrates onto the zeolite particles, where it reacts to produce the Ga+Z- species, according to equation (4b). The resulting overall process is equation (3). Focusing our attention on the migration of Ga20species, we have noticed in a previous section that for HZ/Ga203samples no significant transfer phenomena occurred below 673 K. This important finding can be related (a) to the sublimation temperature of Ga20, which is higher than 773 K [ 34 ] , and (b), as recently shown by Chang Me and Qi Tang .[35], to the commonly observed correlation between the spreading of several inorganic compounds and their respective Tammann temperatures, TT [36]: below TT no spreading can be obtained in a relatively short time (24 h). The TT of Ga20is 603 K. For these reasons, from mechanism (4), we expected that our HZ/Ga203 samples should undergo a slight reduction at temperatures equal or lower than 673 K, our experimental lower limit of the spreading activation temperature. The expected qualitative reduction trend is presented in Fig. 5 (curve B) as a dashed line. However, our experimental results are quite different. The experimental R (T) function of HZ/Ga203, depicted in Fig. 5 (curve C), demonstrates that a relevant amount of gallium can yet be reduced at low temperature. Thus, by means of XPS analysis, it has been pointed out that in presence of HZSM-5 the Ga present on the surface of Ga203particles shifts to the lower oxidation state, GaI, before the Ga20 produced can spread onto the zeolite phase. These experimental results imply a revision of mechanism (3) to take into account the relatively high reduction activity of HZ/Ga203at low temperatures; while the mechanism (3) explains very well the results for the highest reduction temperature used in our experiments (773 K), it is not in accordance with the overall reduction trend of HZ/Ga203. Tentatively, we suggest a mechanism consisting in the following processes: (i) HZ initially undergoes a particular activation probably be due to zeolite sodium or iron impurities at low temperatures or to zeolite superacidic centres at higher temperatures as recently discussed by Jacobs et al. [37]; (ii) the activated hydrogen reaches and reduces the gallium atoms through a surface diffusion process; (iii) if the temperature is sufficiently high, the Ga20 388 R. Carli et al. / J. Mol. Catal. 83 (1993) 379-389 produced spreads into the zeolite, this process becoming the driving force of the reduction; (iv) the spread Ga20 reacts with the zeolite superacid centres, generating a new species of gallium trapped within the zeolite pore structure (Ga'Z- in eqn. (4b)). Although the existence of this gallium species has also been supported by recent results [ 38 ], we feel that reaction (4b) is not necessary during the initial reduction of Ga203- In other words, we suggest that the primary role of HZSM-5 in this system is to provide some activated hydrogen species able to reduce Ga203 to give Ga20, i.e., mechanism (3) should be completed by a new reaction for the hydrogen activation due to HZSM-5 zeolite. To elucidate the nature of activated hydrogen, the mechanism of its formation and its surface diffusion, further study is required. Conclusions High resolution XPS measurements on a Ga203/HZSM-5 catalyst reveal that by in situ hydrogen reduction at low temperatures, in the range 373-673 K, a significant amount of Ga... is reduced to lower oxidation-state species recognized to be GaI. A revision of the existing model is proposed here to explain the observed reduction, particles resulting from the surface transfer of gallium to HZSM-5 having not been detected. We further suggest that the primary role of HZSM5 could be the activation of hydrogen species able to reduce Ga203 even at low temperature. coredata.dc:description: Several experiments were performed to provide convincing evidence for low temperature gallium reduction in a Ga2O3/HZSM-5 catalyst. XPS measurements showed the appearance of a GaI signal after in situ hydrogen reduction at temperatures ranging between 373 and 673 K. No transfer of reduced gallium species from Ga2O3 to the zeolite particles was detected. A revision of the existing reduction mechanism is thus proposed. It is suggested here that the actual role of the HZSM-5 zeolite could be to provide a kind of activated hydrogen able to reduce Ga2O3.
coredata.dc:title: Low temperature reduction of gallium in a Ga2O3/HZSM-5 catalyst
